summary: This document appears to be a set of questions and responses regarding the Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) handling of Jeffrey Epstein while in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, focusing on failures in monitoring, suicide prevention protocols, and specific incidents leading up to his death. The BOP responds to questions about policy, procedures, and specific events but often declines to comment on Epstein specifically.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate at the center of the BOP's failures in monitoring and suicide prevention. The document details his time in custody, his suicide attempt, and the institutional mishandling of his case.

events.title: Delayed Suicide Risk Evaluation
events.description: A recommendation was made that Epstein be evaluated for suicide risk, but the assessment was delayed until July 9.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York.

events.title: Epstein's Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein previously attempted suicide while in custody, which led to a disciplinary process and an incident report that was later expunged.

events.title: Closure of MCC New York
events.description: The Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York City was closed, at least temporarily, following an assessment of necessary improvements, which included issues highlighted by the Epstein case.

keyFacts: BOP records reveal mistakes, sloppiness, and incompetence in dealing with Epstein, including failure to log social calls, delays in psych evaluations, inaccuracies in intake forms, and not providing a cellmate the night he died.
BOP officials concluded they did not appreciate suicide risk factors in Epstein's case quickly enough, such as after his admission and after he was denied bail.
Epstein was subjected to a disciplinary process following his attempted suicide, and the related incident report was later expunged without explanation.
The BOP utilizes 'inmate companions' to monitor inmates on suicide watch, but they do not have direct contact and observe through a cell window.
The closure of the MCC New York was influenced by the need to address systemic issues, some of which were highlighted by the failures in the Epstein case.
